name: Love Stories
description:
Love Stories collects five short comics by Mat Tait drawn in lush black and white including his collaboration with writer Michael Brown "The Heading Dog Who Split in Half".

Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, card cover, saddle stitch, 32 pages.

About Mat Tait:

Mathew Tait is a South Island based comics artist and writer. He gained a BFA in painting from Ilam School of Arts and then lived for a while in America and Britain before returning to New Zealand and settling in Motueka, a small rural town where he does freelance illustrations and works on his art. He has contributed comics to many local and international anthologies, including Kramer's Ergot (USA), Study Group 12 (USA), Pure Evil (Australia) and Comix 2000 (France). His comic Love Stories won the New Zealand Comics Eric Award for Best Comic in 2010.

Reviews of Love Stories
 
File Under Other: "Love Stories contains five short stories. The themes and storytelling techniques vary but the drawing is very strong and consistent throughout. Tait's style is eloquent and efficient but there is also an edginess to the drawing. It may just be the tight shading lines or the boldness of the inks but Tait's characters exist in a world that seems to want to crush or slice them apart in any given panel. Both the writing and the drawing point to the fragility of life."


High-Low Sequart Review: "This is a visually striking collection told in stark and boldly outlined black & white, giving his pages a certain weight while not sacrificing the fluidity of the narrative. Tait's local and Maori stories like "Graveyard Etiquette" (comparing a Maori creation myth to the simultaneous gratitude and resentment children feel toward their parents) and "The Heading Dog Who Split In Half" (about a legendary sheepdog) are crisply told and a delight to look at. "

name: Deep Park
description:
Deep Park

'The beloved amusement park with it all: carousels, drop rides, a hallucinogenic water slide,an orgasm inducing roller coaster and the cult that worships it. Join a colourful cast of characters wasting a day in the sun, exploring the thrills, and terrors, Deep Park has to offer.'
 

Deep Park is a brand new Australian graphic novel from a fresh young voice, here making his book length debut. An equal parts amusing and uncomfortable exploration of repercussions and human failings, the story of Deep Park is presented as seemingly separated vignettes; we follow characters for two or four pages before moving on to another scenario. Only as the book progresses is it revealed how interconnected and co-dependant these stories are, all leading towards a climactic clash between a crazed, genocidal Disney-like figure and a roller coaster worshipping cult of desperation! The fun never stops at Deep Park.

 

About David

David C Mahler was born in Vancouver, Canada, and after a few formative years in Belgium moved to Melbourne at age ten. Raised on a diet of Calvin and Hobbes, Tintin, Archie and Astroboy, drawing was second nature from childhood. He released his first self published mini-comic at age nine.

 

After years of experimenting and developing in the Melbourne small press scene, his quarterly short story comic collection Coracle debuted at the 2013 Melbourne zine fair. As well, he has contributed to magazines and anthologies such as Voiceworks, The Lifted Brow, Naturegraffix, Victoria Drug Scene, Dailies and the upcoming Paper Trail.
 
A current film student at the Victorian College of the Arts, David has also completed a number of short films and animations. Outside of his course, he is currently at work on a weekly web comic, Greyvid, a follow up graphic novel and a mini comic for the Andrew Fulton organized Mini Comic of the Month Club.

Format: 60 pages, digest size, black and white, colour card covers.

name: Dreamboat Dreamboat
description: Dreamboat Dreamboat is set in 1958, Dannevirke, New Zealand and features rock'n'roll entranced teenagers who form a band and become local rock sensations but also encounter some of the unspoken darker elements of society of the time. Toby Morris Online. About Toby Morris: At various points in every day Toby Morris is an illustrator, art director, comic artist and designer. He is a former member of the band Batrider, former editor and publisher of Officer Pup, former artist and writer of the comic series Pirate Technics, and a current father of one. He drew, published and nationally distributed his first comic at age 13 and since then drawn two books, over twenty comics and worked extensively within the New Zealand music industry, drawing posters and covers for the likes of Connan Mockasin, Liam Finn, A Low Hum and Flying Nun records. Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, card cover, saddle stitch, 32 pages.

name: Adversaries
description: Adversaries mini comic by M.Emery Gags and longer stories - Racism, Infidelity, Witches Coven, Gays, Smukey the Sexy bear, Snowmen, Werewolves, all served with a healthy helping of absurdity. Guzumo Comics Format: Mini Comic 155 mm by 155mm, 32 pages, colour and black and white interiors, card cover, saddle stitch.

name: Let Me Be Frank #1
description: First issue in a series of themed comics featuring Sarah Laing's autobiographical stories. Let Me Be Frank #1 focuses on parenting. Sarah Laing's Blog. About Sarah Laing: Sarah Laing is a novelist and graphic designer who lives in Auckland, New Zealand. She has had three books published, The Fall of Light, released in July 2013. She began drawing comics seriously in 2003, when she read Persepolis and was reminded how much she loved the medium. She kept comics diaries of her life as a new mother. These graduated to the internet in 2010, when she was the Frank Sargeson writer in residence in Albert Park. Her blog, Let me be Frank, quickly gained a following and she began contributing to magazines such as Metro, Little Treasures and Booknotes. Sarah is now working on a graphic novel about Katherine Mansfield. Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, card cover, saddle stitch, 32 pages.

name: Let Me Be Frank #2
description: Second issue in a series of themed comics featuring Sarah Laing's autobiographical stories. Let Me Be Frank #2 focuses on consuming. Sarah Laing's Blog. About Sarah Laing: Sarah Laing is a novelist and graphic designer who lives in Auckland, New Zealand. She has had three books published, her most recent, The Fall of Light, released in July 2013. She began drawing comics seriously in 2003, when she read Persepolis and was reminded how much she loved the medium. She kept comics diaries of her life as a new mother. These graduated to the internet in 2010, when she was the Frank Sargeson writer in residence in Albert Park. Her blog, Let me be Frank, quickly gained a following and she began contributing to magazines such as Metro, Little Treasures and Booknotes. Sarah is now working on a graphic novel about Katherine Mansfield. Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, card cover, saddle stitch, 32 pages.

name: Let Me Be Frank #3
description: Third issue in a series of themed comics featuring Sarah Laing's autobiographical stories. Let Me Be Frank #3 focuses on writing. Sarah Laing's Blog. About Sarah Laing: Sarah Laing is a novelist and graphic designer who lives in Auckland, New Zealand. She has had three books published, The Fall of Light, released in July 2013. She began drawing comics seriously in 2003, when she read Persepolis and was reminded how much she loved the medium. She kept comics diaries of her life as a new mother. These graduated to the internet in 2010, when she was the Frank Sargeson writer in residence in Albert Park. Her blog, Let me be Frank, quickly gained a following and she began contributing to magazines such as Metro, Little Treasures and Booknotes. Sarah is now working on a graphic novel about Katherine Mansfield. Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, card cover, saddle stitch, 32 pages.

name: Let Me Be Frank #4
description: Fourth issue in a series of themed comics featuring Sarah Laing's autobiographical stories. Let Me Be Frank #4 focuses on celebrity. Sarah Laing's Blog. About Sarah Laing: Sarah Laing is a novelist and graphic designer who lives in Auckland, New Zealand. She has had three books published, The Fall of Light, released in July 2013. She began drawing comics seriously in 2003, when she read Persepolis and was reminded how much she loved the medium. She kept comics diaries of her life as a new mother. These graduated to the internet in 2010, when she was the Frank Sargeson writer in residence in Albert Park. Her blog, Let me be Frank, quickly gained a following and she began contributing to magazines such as Metro, Little Treasures and Booknotes. Sarah is now working on a graphic novel about Katherine Mansfield. Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, card cover, saddle stitch, 32 pages.

name: EPHEMERA
description:
Anthology of Australian and New Zealand cartoonists featuring:

Jerome Bihan
Barnet Burns
Chris Cudby
Matt Emery
Brendan Halyday
Justin Woolley
Robyn E. Kenealy
Brent Willis

Published by Ephemera Comics 2010

Format: A4, 24 pages, full colour, saddle stitch.

name: Moa Volume One
description:
Moa Volume One collects the first three issues of writer/Illustrator James Davidson's Moa comics in one trade paperback.

Moa features the exploits of Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku in an anthropomorphised version of colonial New Zealand.

Three adventures in this volume include:
Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku battle adversaries in the forests of New Zealand over a mysterious artifact.

Kiwi Pukupuku retells the legend of Hatupatu and with Possum Von Tempsky faces the evil bird woman against a backdrop of Geothermal New Zealand.

Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku encounter Tu-Te-Wehiwehi, an unmovable Kauri, and a big game hunter comes to Timbertown.

Plus extra features behind the making and development of Moa comics.

Format: Standard American comic size, 84 pages, full colour, square bound trade paperback.

name: Moa #1
description: Moa #1 Written and drawn By James Davidson Anthropomorphic adventures of Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku steeped in New Zealand folklore. Moa #1 was originally independently published as a black and white ashcan. Pikitia Press are proud to present a full size, full colour edition of the first adventures of Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku. Contains supplemental pages detailing the creation and development of Moa comics. Moa Blog Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, 32 pages, full colour, card cover, saddle stitch.

name: Moa #2
description: Moa #2 Written and drawn By James Davidson Anthropomorphic adventures of Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku steeped in New Zealand folklore. In Moa #2 Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku encounter the legend of Hatupatu and the evil bird woman. Moa Blog Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, 28 pages, full colour, card cover, saddle stitch.

name: Moa #3
description: Moa #3 Written and drawn By James Davidson. Anthropomorphic adventures of Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku steeped in New Zealand folklore. Kauri Crazy! Possum Von Tempsky and Kiwi Pukupuku encounter Tu-Te-Wehiwehi, an unmovable Kauri, and a big game hunter comes to Timbertown. Moa Blog Format: Standard American Comic Size 17 cm by 26 cm, full colour, card cover, saddle stitch, 24 pages.

name: The Ditko Public Service Package #2
description:
The Ditko Public Service Package #2

A 112 page, black-and-white reprint

This is the 2nd edition of this book and a sequel to an earlier book, Ditko Package.

Featuring Ditko's polemic on the comic industry's business malpractices and lunacy. The characters aren't based on actual people, but there's an assortment of comic book personalities like publishers, the media, accountants, collectors, fanboys and even a mad scientist!

Ditko also does a lot of nice visual gags with animated comic pages and talking art supplies. There's some imaginative, humorous cartooning going on here, with lots of classic Ditko designing and inking. 

Format: Standard American Comic Size, 112 Pages, Black and White, Square bound.

name: The Avenging Mind
description:
Collection of essays and illustrations. including work that originally appeared in Robin Snyder's The Comics! newsletter.

10 essays feature in 26 pages of text with 10 pages of illustrations. Ditko examines the work he did with Stan lee and also comments on the modern incarnation of Marvel comics under the stewardship of Joe Quesada.

by Steve Ditko

Published by Robin Snyder/Steve Ditko 2007

Format: Standard American Comic Size, 36 pages including card cover, newsprint interior pages, saddle stitch.

name: MR. A.
description:
A new edition of the 1973 Mr. A. #1 comic was published by Snyder and Ditko in late 2009. This edition has all the story contents of the original, though with a different story order, the covers and centerfold printed in black and white and the splash page to "Right to Kill!" restored to Ditko's original intent.

Rex Graine is a newspaper reporter for the Daily Crusader. He is known for his uncompromising principles and incorruptibility. In order to fight crime, Graine wears metal gloves and a steel mask that resembles a placid face, thus becoming Mr. A. In keeping with the hardboiled detective theme, both personae typically wear suits and fedora hats; Mr. A's outfit is completely white. There is no origin story for the character, thus the only discernible reason why Graine sometimes disguises himself (both his identities are equally threatened by criminals and sometimes hated by the general public) is due to his choice to become a vigilante. Mr. A uses half white-half black calling cards to signify his arrival, as well as to represent his belief that there can only be good and evil, and no moral grey area.

by Steve Ditko

Published by Robin Snyder/Steve Ditko 2010

Format: Oversize American Comic Size, 36 pages, glossy cover, bond interior pages, saddle stitch.

name: For The Term Of His Natural Life
description:
For The Term Of His Natural Life by Peter Foster

Peter Foster's adaption of Marcus Clarke's classic Australian novel For The Term of His Natural Life. Depicting the hardships of convicts in Tasmania in the early days of the colonisation of Australia. sixty-four pages of vibrant colour with several pages detailing the original creation of one of Australia's first graphic novels and a foreword from Marcus Clarke scholar Laurie Hergenhan.

Praise for 'For The Term of His natural Life'

"This is a fine piece of work...You've executed some brilliant rendering - particularly in the ship sequences but I'm most interested in your skill at human expression; to me a most important element in this medium." - Will Eisner, creator of the Spirit and Graphic Novel pioneer, in correspondence with Peter Foster 1986.

"I was wrong! I once thought that the lively drawings from Peter Foster's graphic novels could not be improved on. But the addition of colour has now made them even more dramatic!" - Rolf Heimann - Emeritus Vice President Australian Cartooning Association Victorian chapter.

"This epic tale comes to life under Peter's pen and brush. His panels depicting the suffering and inhumane treatment of convicts, drama of storms at sea, sailing ships, costumes and uniforms of the era also reveal the vast amount of research necessary for such a whopping graphic project. This wonderfully illustrated work will make a significant contribution to the enjoyment of a new generation of readers, particularly those devotees of the graphic novel." - Multi award winning cartoonist/illustrator George Haddon.

Format: A4, 64 pages, full colour, perfect bound.

name: BALLANTYNE: WHERE HIDDEN RIVERS FLOW
description:
Ballantyne: Where Hidden Rivers Flow reprints artist Peter Foster’s collaboration with writer James H. Kemsley, originally running as a newspaper strip  in the Sydney Sunday Sun-Herald for several years during the 1990s.

Based on Kemsley’s vivid memories of working as a patrol officer in post World War Two New Guinea, Ballantyne is a classic adventure strip in the fine tradition of Lee Falk's The Phantom and John Dixon's Air Hawk.

For this volume Peter Foster has coloured and reformatted the daily Ballantyne strips to produce a vibrant dynamic comic book.

Published by Pikitia Press 2012.

Format: A4, 64 pages, full colour, perfect bound.

name: Ballantyne Vol Two: The Spirit of The Stone
description:
Ballantyne: The Spirit of The Stone is the second volume of artist Peter Foster’s collaboration with writer James H. Kemsley, originally featured as a newspaper adventure strip in the Sydney Sunday Sun-Herald during the 1990s.

Based on Kemsley’s vivid memories of working as a patrol officer in post World War Two New Guinea, Ballantyne is a classic adventure strip in the fine tradition of Lee Falk's The Phantom and John Dixon's Air Hawk.

For this volume Peter Foster has coloured and reformatted the daily Ballantyne strips to produce a vibrant dynamic comic book.

Published by Pikitia Press 2012.

Format: A4, 40 pages, full colour, saddle stitch.

name: Ballantyne: The Flaw In The Jewel
description:
Ballantyne: The Flaw in the Jewel is the third volume of artist Peter Foster’s collaboration with writer James H. Kemsley, originally featured as a newspaper adventure strip in the Sydney Sunday Sun-Herald during the 1990s.

In his third volume patrol officer Peter Ballantyne comes up against a corrupt plantation owner and poachers in the wilds of New Guinea.

Based on Kemsley’s vivid memories of working as a patrol officer in post World War Two New Guinea, Ballantyne is a classic adventure strip in the fine tradition of Lee Falk's The Phantom and John Dixon's Air Hawk.

For this volume Peter Foster has coloured and reformatted the daily Ballantyne strips to produce a vibrant dynamic comic book.

Also included in this volume is a previously uncollected story Sports INC, another collaboration between Kemsley and Foster. Sports INC was conceived as a daily newspaper strip for syndication but was only ever run in one newspaper.

Published by Pikitia Press 2013.

Format: A4, 52pages, full colour, saddle stitch.

name: The Return Of The Night Eagle
description:
Peter Foster revamps Carl Lyon's Aussie hero of the 1940's as a legacy hero with an adventure story that recaptures the magic of the early day's of the Australian comic industry. Back up feature, Orion the Hunter, originally appeared in an issue of Gerald Carr's Vixen. 

Return of the Night Eagle also contains recollections of Peter's involvement in Australian comics and the Australian Cartooning Association.

Published by Pikitia Press 2012

Format: A4, 40 pages, full colour, saddle stitch.

name: Spirit Fingers
description:
Spirit Fingers Written and drawn by Melbourne cartoonist Maude Farrugia Autobio comics and other comics about the occupy movement, protest, freedom and political concerns. stitchbound, A5, 12 pages + cover, black and white

Maude Farrugia Blog

name: Rags
description: Rags Written and drawn by Melbourne cartoonist Maude Farrugia Maude describes Rags as, "Another messy-scribbled-comic about radical ideas and stuff that gets me worked up!" stitchbound, A5, 8 pages + cover, black and white Maude Farrugia Blog
